tagline: Validate YAML syntax instantly with detailed error reporting
pageDescription: Free online YAML validator checks your YAML syntax and reports errors with exact line numbers. Supports YAML 1.1 and 1.2 specifications, validates Kubernetes manifests, Docker Compose files, GitHub Actions workflows, and any YAML configuration. Features include syntax highlighting, duplicate key detection, pretty formatting, and structure visualization. Browser-based with complete privacy - your data never leaves your device.

instructions.title: How to use YAML Validator

steps.title: Paste your YAML
steps.description: Enter or paste your YAML content in the input area. The validator accepts any valid YAML including multi-document files.

steps.title: Click Validate
steps.description: Click the Validate button to check your YAML syntax. Validation happens instantly in your browser.

steps.title: Review results
steps.description: If valid, you'll see a success message with parsed structure. If invalid, you'll get detailed error messages with line numbers.

steps.title: Fix and re-validate
steps.description: Use the error information to fix issues in your YAML, then validate again until all errors are resolved.

features: Detailed error messages with line numbers
useCases: Check Docker Compose files for syntax errors
Learn YAML syntax with instant feedback
Ensure config files are properly formatted
proTips: Use consistent indentation (2 or 4 spaces, never tabs)
Quote strings that start with special characters
Use the structure view to understand nested data
Check for duplicate keys which can cause silent bugs
Validate before committing to version control
Use multi-document syntax (---) for related configs
Pay attention to colons followed by spaces
Boolean values: use true/false, not yes/no for clarity
troubleshooting: Indentation error: YAML uses spaces, not tabs. Check that indentation is consistent throughout the file.
Unexpected end of stream: Usually means unclosed quotes or brackets. Check for matching pairs.
Duplicate key: Same key appears twice in a mapping. Rename or remove the duplicate.
Bad indentation of a mapping entry: Child elements must be indented more than parents.
Could not find expected ':': Missing colon after a key. Add ': ' after the key name.
Block sequence entries not allowed in this context: Check that list items are properly indented.
Implicit keys need to be on a single line: Long keys should use explicit notation with '?'.
Tab character in indentation: Replace tabs with spaces (usually 2 per level).
